image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from South Carolina; born Elizabeth Mills Hawley on February 26, 1886, near Blythewood, on Rice Creek Plantation, Richland County, S.C.; attended South Carolina Coeducational Institute, Edgefield, S.C.; graduated from Greenville Female College, Greenville, S.C., 1907; elected as a Democrat to the Seventy-fifth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of her husband, Allard H. Gasque, (September 13, 1938-January 3, 1939); was not a candidate for election to the Seventy-sixth Congress; author; lecturer; died on November 2, 1989, in Cedar Tree Plantation, Ridgeway, S.C.

note.content: Elected September 13, 1938, to fill vacancy caused by death of her husband, Allard H. Gasque, but was unable to sworn in as Congress was not in session.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: "Elizabeth Hawley Gasque" in Women in Congress, 1917-2006. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2006.

researchRecord.name: In the Allard Henry Gasque Papers, 1920-1938, 6.25 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Papers documenting the service of Elizabeth Gasque are included in the papers of her husband, Allard Gasque. Included is constituent correspondence, materials relating to the Depression, politics, the appointment of postmasters, and the Inland Waterway. A finding aid is available in the repository.
